trial_identification.studytitle: A randomised trial of Anterior 180 degree vs Nissen fundoplication to control and assess the contol of reflux and side effects in patients undergonig surgery for gastro-oesophageal reflux
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised trial of Anterior 180 degree vs Nissen fundoplication to control and assess the contol of reflux and side effects in patients undergonig surgery for gastro-oesophageal reflux

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal oral and gastrointestinal development and function

interventions.interventions: 2 types of fundoplication for gastro-oesophageal reflux compared. 1) Nissen (total) fundoplication 2) Anterior 180 degree partial (stomach sutured across front of oesophagus) fundoplication.
interventions.comparator: Comparison of 2 equally valid procedures in RCT

primaryOutcome.outcome: Dysphagia and reflux symptoms will be determined using a clinical questionnaire
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At 3 months, and then yearly for 20 years

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Dysphagia and other symptoms will be determined using a clinical questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At 3 months, and then yearly for 20 years.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Suitable for a laparoscopic Nissen fundoplication
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Not suitable for laparoscopic Nissen fundoplicationsevere oesophageal motility disorder

trial_design.sequence: 120 Envelopes prepared by independent nurse (60 = treatment, 60=control), and shuffled extensively.
trial_design.designfeatures: patients and nurse undertaking follow-up blinded as to which operation was performed

fundingsource.fundingname: National Health and Medical Research Council

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Random assignment to either Nissen or anterior partial fundoplication. Outcome is relfux control and side effects (especially dysphagia)
